physical_appearance:This is a batik hanging. It features flowers on vines set against a plain maroon background. The floral vines are placed in the center of the hanging with a drawn lattice fence. There are several butterflies flying above the flowers. There is a signature at the bottom-right of the design.
subject_terms_1:Peranakan flower (motif)
subject_terms_2:Batik Draperies Peranakan (Asian people) Motifs
subject_terms_3:Batik
sgcool_label_text:Flowers on vines set against a plain maroon background is shown on this sarong.  Occupying the centre of the cloth
 the placement of the wooden rack gives the design an illusion of two-dimensionality.  The use of filler motifs results in gradations of colour and adds depth to the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono Java ‘78”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik hanging. It features flowers on vines set against a plain maroon background. The floral vines are placed in the center of the hanging with a drawn lattice fence. There are several butterflies flying above the flowers. There is a signature at the bottom-right of the design.
metadata.sgcool_label_text: Flowers on vines set against a plain maroon background is shown on this sarong.  Occupying the centre of the cloth, the placement of the wooden rack gives the design an illusion of two-dimensionality.  The use of filler motifs results in gradations of colour and adds depth to the overall design.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Jane Hendromartono Java ‘78”.
